arts.ttl: ‘I’m not happy with how we played’ - QPR boss reacts to Millwall derby draw
arts.sum: There are a lot of set-plays and disruptions, so it’s difficult to build momentum, and we simply weren’t good enough to impose the way we wanted to at home.” “The first half was very slow, and we improved a little bit in the second half – but it wasn’t good enough to really challenge them in the final third,” Cifuentes admitted.

arts.ttl: The lowdown on QPR 1 Millwall 1 - Watmore’s goal run continues as Ivanovic gets first taste of Championship football
arts.sum: Millwall: Jensen, Leonard, Cooper, Tanganga, Bryan, De Norre, Saville, Honeyman (Wintle 90+3), Watmore (Azeez 75), Esse, Langstaff (Ivanovic 75). Langstaff produced his best display yet in a Millwall shirt, collecting the assist for Watmore’s goal and also sett up George Honeyman for a strike which narrowly flew just wide of Nardi’s goal.

arts.ttl: Liverpool loanee defender will miss at least next two months of Millwall’s season
arts.sum: Liverpool loanee Calum Scanlon is facing at least two months on the Millwall sidelines. Asked about Scanlon after Millwall’s 1-1 draw at QPR today, head coach Neil Harris said: “He has got a stress fracture in his back, which is a recurring injury from previous.

arts.ttl: Millwall boss Harris focusing on positives to come out of 1-1 draw at QPR
arts.sum: Harris said: “Glass half-full, for sure, because historically it has been a notoriously difficult place for a Millwall team to come to and get positive results over the years. Millwall had a huge chance in the second half to go back ahead but George Honeyman could not get any kind of significant touch on Romain Esse’s cutback from close range.

arts.ttl: QPR hit back to hold Millwall
arts.sum: QPR and Millwall drew 1-1 in an uninspiring London derby at Loftus Road.

arts.ttl: QPR and Millwall take a point each after derby draw
arts.sum: The goals came in the first half.

arts.ttl: Neil Harris agrees with former boss Rowett that Premier League clubs will be watching Millwall’s Esse
arts.sum: Neil Harris has agreed with former boss Gary Rowett that Premier League clubs will be watching Romain Esse – but says the attacker’s main focus will be on ensuring he is a constant fixture in the Millwall side this season. Rowett, who handed Esse his Lions debut during his stint as boss at The Den, was a pundit for Sky Sports for Millwall’s game against Luton last Saturday.

arts.ttl: 'I was a Chelsea hooligan – this is why West Ham was scarier than Millwall to visit'
arts.sum: Notorious football hooligan Pat Dolan has revealed that Upton Park was a far worse ground to visit than The Den despite its reputation - revisiting a particularly terrifying incident in the 1980s

arts.ttl: Colback returns: QPR team news and predicted XI to face Millwall
arts.sum: QPR come into this weekend’s clash with Millwall looking to make if five Championship games without tasting defeat.… The post Colback returns: QPR team news and predicted XI to face Millwall appeared first on The72 - Football League News.

arts.ttl: Millwall boss Neil Harris urges Macaulay Langstaff to be patient in hunt for first goal
arts.sum: Neil Harris believes Macaulay Langstaff’s natural goalscoring instinct will see him open his Millwall account – but has reminded the summer signing to be patient as he adapts to the jump from League Two to the Championship. “Macaulay has a history of scoring goals – a lot of them – he’s desperate to score goals.
